justification: The package contains a very large amount of code and many classes concentrated in a few huge components: num_classes=51 and loc=6908 at package level. Several classes are extremely large and complex (examples: FastDatePrinter loc=1132 wmc=102, DateUtils loc=1095 wmc=128, FastDateParser loc=764 wmc=77, DurationFormatUtils loc=561 wmc=85, StopWatch loc=549 wmc=56, FastDateFormat loc=422 wmc=44). Many of these classes include numerous nested/inner types and high method counts (e.g. DateUtils nom=67, FastDatePrinter has many inner Rule types), indicating a concentration of responsibilities. By contextual judgment (high total LOC, high number of classes and multiple very large/complex classes within the same package) this package exhibits the God Component smell.

The package has 7 classes and 734 LOC, which is not an excessive number of classes and a moderate total size. However, size and complexity are concentrated in a single class: Streams has 384 LOC (≈52% of the package), 21 methods and WMC 21, while other classes are much smaller (LangCollectors 95 LOC, Streams.FailableStream 121 LOC, nested small collectors/spliterators). This distribution indicates a large/god-like class within the package (Streams) rather than the package itself being a God Component. Therefore the package does not qualify as a God Component based on the provided data.

The package concentrates a large portion of its code in a single component/file: total package LOC = 947 while LockingVisitors (one class/file) alone is 440 LOC (~46% of package LOC) and LockingVisitors.LockVisitor is 215 LOC, so two nested types account for ~69% of the package LOC. The package contains 9 classes but the LOC distribution is highly skewed toward the LockingVisitors file with multiple nested visitor and builder types defined there, indicating centralized responsibilities and excessive size in that component. This concentration of functionality and large class/file size supports detection of a God Component.

The package contains 61 classes and 2,551 LOC, which is large for a single component. In particular it houses very large, high-complexity classes: Failable (LOC=467, NOM=37, WMC=45) and MethodInvokers (LOC=122, NOM=13, WMC=13). Failable also lists many dependencies on other function types, indicating it centralizes a lot of functionality. Although many other classes are small functional interfaces, the high class count combined with substantial LOC and concentrated complexity in key classes shows the package is excessively large and likely bundles too many responsibilities, consistent with a God Component smell.

The package contains only 2 classes and 463 LOC overall, so it is not excessively large as a component. Although one class (FluentBitSet) is dominant — 396 LOC (≈85% of package LOC), 44 methods (nom) and WMC 49 — the package as a whole does not have a large number of classes or an unusually high total size. The metrics indicate a concentration of complexity in a single class rather than an excessively large component.

The package contains 13 classes and 746 LOC, which is moderate and the implementation is distributed across many small-to-medium classes rather than concentrated in one huge component. No single class dominates the package by LOC (largest classes: EntityArrays 106 LOC, NumericEntityUnescaper 95 LOC, UnicodeEscaper 94 LOC, CharSequenceTranslator 91 LOC) and class complexity (WMC) values remain relatively low (mostly <=13). Package coupling is low (Ce=1, Ca=1) and class fan-in/fan-out are zero for most classes, indicating responsibilities are not centralized into a single god component. Therefore, the evidence does not support labeling this package a God Component.

The package is excessively large: 29 classes and 6,366 LOC overall with a heavy concentration of code in a few very large classes. Notable large/complex classes include ToStringStyle (LOC 1694, NOM 113, WMC 191), EqualsBuilder (LOC 720, NOM 42, WMC 126), ToStringBuilder (LOC 646, NOM 63, WMC 68), CompareToBuilder (LOC 620, NOM 31, WMC 115), HashCodeBuilder (LOC 507, WMC 72) and ReflectionToStringBuilder (LOC 440, WMC 52), plus DiffBuilder (LOC 421). Several classes alone account for a large fraction of the package LOC and high method counts/complexity, indicating the component centralizes too much responsibility and size, which supports the God Component detection.

The package has 4 classes and 398 LOC, but one class (EventListenerSupport) accounts for 219 LOC (~55% of the package), has 15 methods (highest in the package) and WMC 17, while the other top-level classes are much smaller (EventUtils 84 LOC; nested handlers 43 and 52 LOC). This strong concentration of size and complexity in a single class indicates the package's responsibilities are overly centralized, consistent with a God Component smell.

The package contains only 3 classes (num_classes=3) and 219 LOC overall, with the largest class (Processor) at 153 LOC and 11 methods (nom=11, wmc=11). Coupling is very low (Ce=0, Ca=1, fanin/fanout=0) and cohesion metrics are acceptable (lcom=0). Given the small number of classes, moderate total LOC, lack of high complexity or heavy coupling, this does not meet the contextual threshold for a God Component.

The package contains only 3 classes and a total of 288 LOC, which is not excessively large for a package. The largest class (ComparableUtils) is 171 LOC with 10 methods, while the other two classes are small (43 LOC and 74 LOC). There is no extreme concentration of many classes or overwhelming LOC in the package, and dependency indicators (Ce=0, Ca=1, low fan-in/fan-out) do not suggest a single oversized component. Based on this contextual information, the package does not qualify as a God Component.

The package contains 9 classes and 1,884 LOC, which is moderate rather than excessively large. Individual classes are fairly uniform (several numeric Mutable* classes around 260–280 LOC with nom ~30 and wmc ~31–32) and represent narrow, repeated responsibilities (primitive/object mutable wrappers). Cohesion indicators (LCOM values ~0.06–0.29) are low (high cohesion), fanin/fanout are 0 for most classes, and package coupling is low (Ce=1, Ca=3). There is no evidence of a single class or the package aggregating many unrelated responsibilities; the size stems from repeated, focused wrapper classes. Therefore this package does not qualify as a God Component.

The package has a high total size (loc=2111) concentrated in only 3 classes, indicating excessive volume in a small component. Two classes are very large: NumberUtils (loc=1271, nom=68, nopm=62, wmc=196) and Fraction (loc=660, nom=34, wmc=97), with a third smaller class IEEE754rUtils (loc=180). The large LOC, high number of methods and high complexity metrics (wmc) in these classes show the package centralizes a lot of functionality, supporting the detection of a God Component.

The package has a large overall size (5402 LOC across 20 classes) with extreme concentration of code in a few classes: StrBuilder (2304 LOC, 150 methods, WMC 341), StrTokenizer (731 LOC, 64 methods, WMC 100) and StrSubstitutor (782 LOC, 55 methods, WMC 98). These very large classes (high LOC, many methods and high complexity) indicate a single component carrying excessive responsibilities. The package's low external coupling (Ce=2, Ca=1) and the skewed LOC distribution support the judgment that this package contains a God Component.

The package has 14 classes and 3,368 LOC but three classes dominate size: TypeUtils (LOC 1,363, WMC 236, NOM 59), MethodUtils (LOC 674, WMC 76, NOM 34) and FieldUtils (LOC 584, WMC 48, NOM 36). Those three (3 of 14 classes) account for ~77.8% of the package LOC (2,621/3,368), showing excessive concentration of code and responsibilities in a few components. TypeUtils itself contains many public methods and nested types (multiple inner classes), further indicating a single oversized component. These metrics support detection of a God Component in this package.

The package contains 6 classes and 795 LOC, which is moderate and does not indicate an excessively large component in context. Class sizes are evenly distributed (~113–159 LOC) with moderate WMC values (8–18) and no single class dominating the package. Coupling is low (Ce=1, Ca=1, fanin/fanout mostly 0) and cohesion metrics (LCOM values around 0.25–0.42) do not suggest a sprawling, unfocused component. Given these elements, there is insufficient evidence to classify this package as a God Component.

The package contains 10 classes and 1,061 LOC, with a strong concentration of size and complexity in a single class. ExceptionUtils alone is 575 LOC (≈54% of the package LOC) with 42 methods (nom) and WMC 82, indicating high internal complexity and responsibility. Other classes are moderate (ContextedException and ContextedRuntimeException 126 LOC each, DefaultExceptionContext 99 LOC), but no other class approaches ExceptionUtils' size. This skew—one very large, complex class within a relatively small package—supports identifying the package as a God Component (excessive size concentrated in a component).

The package contains a large amount of code (3203 LOC) spread over many classes (42). Several classes are individually large and complex (TimedSemaphore: 309 LOC, WMC 30; EventCountCircuitBreaker: 316 LOC, WMC 22; BackgroundInitializer: 235 LOC, WMC 21; BasicThreadFactory: 227 LOC, WMC 14; ConcurrentUtils: 202 LOC, WMC 19), indicating concentrated responsibility and complexity. Multiple nested/builder classes and many methods (nom values up to 21) further show the package aggregates diverse functionality. Taken together (high total LOC, high class count, multiple large/high-WMC classes) this matches the God Component smell: the component is excessively large and likely doing too much.

The package is excessively large: 73 classes and 26,295 LOC. It contains multiple very large, complex classes that dominate the package (ArrayUtils: 5,740 LOC, nom 377, wmc 870; StringUtils: 4,411 LOC, nom 244, wmc 713; SystemProperties: 2,807 LOC, nom 205, wmc 206; Conversion: 1,110 LOC, wmc 245; ClassUtils: 1,088 LOC, nom 66, wmc 157). Several of these large classes also show signs of low cohesion/complexity (e.g., Validate lcom 0.9259, ObjectUtils lcom 0.7308, Conversion lcom 0.6744). The package has many methods and high complexity concentrated in a few classes, plus broad dependencies to many subpackages, indicating a monolithic component that fits the God Component smell.
